pullRequest.body:
Relate the `L`-function of a character mod `M` and that of the corresponding imprimitive character modulo a multiple `N` of `M`. 

Co-authored-by: Michael Stoll <Michael.Stoll@uni-bayreuth.de>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

@MichaelStollBayreuth @CBirkbeck Here's the PR for the level-change results. It's marked WIP for now, I think maybe some more polishing is needed before we ask others to review.
I think this is ready for (wider) review now, so I've removed the "WIP" flag.
I have fixed the naming inconsistency, and used "fun_prop" to simplify some continuity / differentiability proofs.
Thanks Johan! I have pushed a fix with the case change & added a remark giving reasons for the choice of name.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11531963030/job/32103254540)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11532320704/job/32103996855)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11532320704/job/32103996754)
Apart from one comment about names, this looks good to me.

Looks good to me now.
(Note: the code is originally due to @loefflerd, with some minor improvements by me.)

Looks good to me now.
(Note: the code is originally due to @loefflerd, with some minor improvements by me.)
Apart from one comment about names, this looks good to me.

```suggestion
  -- convert to a form suitable for `tprod_subtype`
  have (f : Primes  ) : ' (p : Primes), f p = ' (p : {p :  | p.Prime}), f p := rfl
  rw [this, tprod_subtype _ fun p :   (1 - (changeLevel hMN ) p * p ^ (-s)),
    this, tprod_subtype _ fun p :   (1 -  p * p ^ (-s)),  tprod_mul]
  rotate_left -- deal with convergence goals first
   exact multipliable_subtype_iff_mulIndicator.mp
      (dirichletLSeries_eulerProduct_hasProd  hs).multipliable
   exact multipliable_subtype_iff_mulIndicator.mp Multipliable.of_finite
```

```suggestion
     simp only [hp', false_and, reduceIte, inv_inj, sub_right_inj, mul_eq_mul_right_iff,
        cpow_eq_zero_iff, Nat.cast_eq_zero, h.ne_zero, ne_eq, neg_eq_zero, or_false]
      have hq : IsUnit (p : ZMod N) := (ZMod.isUnit_prime_iff_not_dvd h).mpr hp'
      simp only [hq.unit_spec  DirichletCharacter.changeLevel_eq_cast_of_dvd  hMN hq.unit,
        ZMod.cast_natCast hMN]
```

Move to `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Continuity` and add the following to `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Deriv` ?

```lean
lemma differentiable_cpow_natCast_neg (n : ) [NeZero n] : Differentiable  fun s :   (n : ) ^ (-s) :=
  Differentiable.const_cpow differentiable_neg (.inl <| NeZero.ne (n : ))
```

It would probably make sense to extend this to statements on `fun s  1 - c * n ^ (-s)` (with a constant `c`); in this form it is used a few times.
I've added it to the upstream files. I'm not convinced about `1 - c * n ^ (-s)`, I had a look for where the new lemma could be used and the examples I found mostly weren't of that shape.

The cases where these lemmas are applied are actually all about `1 - c * n ^ (-s)`.
But maybe a better approach is to teach `fun_prop` to use the two new lemmas; then these three proofs should reduce to just `fun_prop`.

```suggestion
  have hpc : IsPreconnected ({1} : Set ) := 
    (isConnected_compl_singleton_of_one_lt_rank (rank_real_complex  Nat.one_lt_ofNat) _)
      |>.isPreconnected
```

```suggestion
 apply DifferentiableOn.analyticOnNhd (fun s hs  ?_) isOpen_compl_singleton
    apply ((differentiableAt_LFunction _ _ (.inl hs)).mul ?_).differentiableWithinAt
    refine .finset_prod fun i hi  ?_
    apply (differentiableAt_const _).sub ((differentiableAt_const _).mul ?_)
    apply differentiableAt_id.neg.const_cpow
    exact .inl (mod_cast (Nat.pos_of_mem_primeFactors hi).ne')
```
this is just slightly quicker
Is "apply" really quicker to process than "refine"? I feel it shouldn't be, somehow, because `apply` does more guesswork.

Yeah in general that might be the case, here when trying to golf the proof I noticed that with apply it had about 100 fewer heartbeats, which isn't much of a difference. So I'm happy for you to ignore the suggestion.

```suggestion
    exact (differentiableAt_LFunction _ _ (.inl hs)).differentiableWithinAt
```
Here the lemma `differentiable_cpow_natCast_neg` could be useful.

```suggestion
with ` p  N.primeFactors, (1 -  p * p ^ (-s))`.
(Note that `1 -  p * p ^ (-s) = 1` when `p` divides `M`). -/
```

```suggestion
    exact
      congrFun ((differentiable_LFunction h).continuous.ext_on (dense_compl_singleton 1) h' H) s
```

```suggestion
## The `L`-function of the trivial character mod `N`
```

```suggestion
      ( <|  p  N.primeFactors, (1 - (p : ))) := by
```
This is a use case for the proposed `differentiable_one_sub_const_mul_const_cpow_neg`.
This is a use case for the proposed `continuous_one_sub_const_mul_const_cpow_neg`.
This is another use case for `continuous__one_sub_const_mul_const_cpow_neg`.

You changed `LFunction_one` to `LFunction_triv_char` here, but not in the lemma names below.
Since it is define as `LFunction 1`, I think `LFunction_one` may actually be the better name. In any case, lemma names referring to it should be consistent with its name.

Was the decision to stick with `LFunction_triv_char` recorded somewhere?

Anyways, since this is a def (abbrev) I think it should be CamelCased.
```suggestion
noncomputable abbrev LFunctionTrivChar (N : ) [NeZero N] :=
```
or possibly
```suggestion
noncomputable abbrev LFunctionOne (N : ) [NeZero N] :=
```

Michael's approval tick and message "looks good to me now" was after this, so I took that to include approval of my decision to stick with "triv char" and adjust the lemma names to match. (I don't like "LFunction_one" since it depends on exactly _which_ 1 you are talking about  it is the "1" of the group of Dirichlet characters mod N, and the value of N definitely matters.)

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/LSeries): changeLevel and Dirichlet L-functions
